posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Speaking as someone who read and enjoyed both of his 12 Rules books, he's a quack. He just happened to be in the right place at the right time and said a few things that were pretty basic self-help that some people needed to hear, so a lot of people (myself included) were able to project the most charitable and personally useful interpretations of his words onto him. But the deeper you dive, the more you realise he's an actual lunatic.
His books are... fine... They present pretty no-brainer concepts and just wrap them in a bunch of pseudoscience, psychobabble and spiritualism. If you'd already read them, I would say it is what it is and you don't need to throw the baby out with the bathwater if you got something from them. But if you haven't read them, they're hardly a must read.

I'd say 'The Subtle Art Of Not Giving A Fuck' seems like it presents a lot of the same lessons in a more pragmatic way - granted, that's presumption on my part, since I haven't read that one and have only seen a few videos by/interviews with the author. But they seem similar in the sense of taking responsibility for your life and being more mindful/proactive towards your emotional responses to things - basically giving yourself an attitude adjustment. But, fitting title, The Subtle Art is lightyears less pretentious, which might be doubly better for you if you struggle with feeling like you're not smart enough. You don't need to deal with JBP pontificating for pages on end about his made up nonsense peppered with biblical allusions and convenient misinformation just to explain something as simple as 'stop and smell the roses'. While reading the 12 Rules books, I'd routinely forget the rule that any given chapter was even trying to explain while reading it, simply because he goes on such weird and elaborate tangents.

Eventually all of those experiences changed me. It took awhile but you and do something over and over and over again and not experience growth. Like if you played basketball twice a week for 6 months there’s no way you won’t get better.

So eventually I just got better at getting women. But they weren’t coming to me. I was still approaching them but being smoother about it and had better instincts in dates about what to say and how to converse and stuff. I got laid a lot for a while.

Then after like a year of that lifestyle, I woke up one day and was depressed. A hot girl had left my place after a great night and I should have been happy but I wasn’t. I felt shallow. I didn’t want a relationship but I didn’t want to womanize anymore. so suddenly I stopped wanting to get women.

This new perspective came over me and for several weeks I just started doing my own thing. Then all of the sudden hot women started APPROACHING me.

I’d be in the laundry room at my apartment.. I’d be walking down the street in a college area… I’d be sitting by myself at a bar just sipping a whisky minding my business…. It was crazy dude… I just got flocked by women because I had become genuinely aloof. I didn’t even want them anymore.

conclusion: if you want women spend time trying to get them so that you get good at it and burn out and stop wanting them. once you don’t want them anymore, women will start approaching you.

This one girl is no one my man. Relax.

>>27977912
Whatever possessed you to think any of that was a good idea?
>Wait a bit,
No, if she's down you set it up immediately. Anyone who tells you to intentionally wait is a massive retard and I can't believe that shitty advice has been regurgitated so often and so fervently.
>i tell her i want to go there next thursday and if she wants to tag along
No, none of that shit. The way you asked her out is atrocious because:
>You tell her you'll go there with or without her, so you're indifferent to her tagging along
>And tagging along is what a friend does, not a date
>You tell her you'll either go there alone (so you're a friendless loser) or with friends (so it won't be a real date if she joins you)
>You tell her you're going there on thursday, a day where people usually work or have classes or whatever, making it seem that you don't do anything productive with your time.
>You tell her you're going there on thursday no matter what, so if she really can't for any reason, you leave yourself no room to retreat and reschedule. Can't ask her to go with you to that restaurant on saturday when you went there on thursday, can you?
What you SHOULD have done is
>She says shes down
>tell her you should go on a date there next saturday
>If she says she can't, immediately reschedule for a later day
>If she can't for a second time, that's where it's over and you know she's not interested (But if that was the case, she wouldn't have said she's down for that restaurant)
There. That simple.

I made a small talk cheat sheet a while ago. Maybe it’ll help someone here who needs some help:

Small talk cheat sheet
•Grease the wheels early with a platonic compliment.
•Transition between topics using “reminds me of” thinking.
•Ping for topics of mutual interest.
•Get them excited about the conversation. Ask “why” and “how” questions—peel the onion and ask questions that are fun to answer.
•Create a connection with them while listening. Mirror while listening to make the person feel heard and to build rapport.

I used to sleep around in college but that's because I only had two girlfriends in high school and only had sex once until I was like 19. I felt pretty inexperienced.

>How does your self worth stay intact letting yourself be used like someone's sex toy?
It's an investment/cost thing. I didn't mind it because that's all I genuinely wanted was to indulge in sexual desires. It was validating me (in my eyes at the time) that I was attractive and worth being desired physically. If I was looking for a relationship and using casual sex to get it I would have been very unhappy. But now 4 years later I don't value casual sex really at all, so the last few times I've done it I felt hollow and sad because I wanted more. I don't do it anymore because of it.

I don't think you're a weird outsider. It's just about what stage of life you're in and what you're wanting out of it. I don't think either are bad as long as you're being safe (as far as casual encounters can be) and getting tested

posts.com:
It can be challenging to meet new people and form romantic connections, especially if you are not interested in going to bars or clubs or using dating apps. Here are a few suggestions for other ways you can meet people and potentially form romantic connections:

Join a social group or club: There are many social groups and clubs that you can join that may align with your interests and hobbies. This can be a good way to meet new people and potentially form romantic connections with people who share similar interests.

Volunteer: Volunteering is a great way to meet new people and do something positive for your community. You may be able to find volunteer opportunities that align with your interests and values, which can be a great way to meet like-minded people.

Take a class: Taking a class in something you are interested in can be a great way to meet new people and potentially form romantic connections. You may be able to find classes at a community center, university, or online.

Attend events: There are many events and activities that you can attend that may be a good way to meet new people and potentially form romantic connections. These might include concerts, festivals, sporting events, or other social gatherings.

It is important to remember that forming romantic connections takes time and effort, and it is not always easy to find the right person. It is also important to be open to new experiences and to not limit yourself to specific places or situations. Finally, it is important to be true to yourself and to be comfortable with who you are, as this can help you

I get it actually (29 / M).

A coworker basically asked me what are you doing this weekend, but I replied "just staying home, I don't do anything" - kind of felt bad because I liked her as far as work goes and hoped she wouldn't take offense, but because I just didn't feel like a relationship with her on a lot of levels - i.e. she was really perfectionist / hard worker versus my slacker's mentality, she was really offended by any type of edgy language / humor, and I am an autist who stays home watching horror movies, playing video games, researching conspiracies. The major reason why I politely declined was that I knew she liked me, and that she had a high opinion of me - whereas my real personality and lifestyle would not only be incompatible but also invalidate her perception of me, and I have a bad pattern of disappointing people I like / respect so I didn't want that to happen. I'm fairly sure 90% of guys would not have cared, and went on the date for better or worse. That would probably be the rational course of action, but it wasn't mine and I don't exactly regret that.

My point is not all men are same, anymore than all women. I've struggled with "porn" addiction yet I've virtually never watched actual pornography because naked people, genitalia, and images of people having sex are grotesque to me. My "material" was always stuff like pictures of women dressed nicely, characters from anime, or in the last several years kpop fancams. Whenever I tell other people in the NoFap community that I barely ever actually watched "porn", they react like I have three heads. We all don't live according to what's normal, and there's a significant difference between talking to women you know and approaching strangers, unless you're really high confidence. That's probably what OP should work on.

Life sucks because it's short and always fighting against death. You will never get anything good out of it; money, intelligence and strength won't save you from death. Life hurts; it's painful and sometimes it will put you so low that you can't keep going onward. Hell, you could lose your legs, or your eyes maybe even have your head attached to a computer giving you sustenance but no matter what, you're going out the same way as everybody else and that is where the whole notion of ending it just fucking shatters. You aren't here to be fed happiness, that's just a stupid chemical released in your brain whenever a slight change occurs in your life - utterly pointless and a waste of fucking time hanging your head up missing happiness whenever it passes away into your memories. You're here to fulfil a duty and you don't even realize it. You're fulfilling it every time you speak, every time you listen to someone else speak, hell; it happens when you just stand there doing fucking nothing. You have to be patient until you eat it up to the point it hurts no more. Your psyche is like a shin being conditioned for Muay Thai - the pain is NEVER going to go away but the shin becomes stronger every time it eats pain. That is what you have to remember in the end, that it doesn't matter what you feel like, existence requires you because you yourself exist.

>>27979835
>Something seasonal
Winter light show in the Winter, Apple Orchard/Pumpkin patch in the Fall, Arboretum in the Spring, that kind of thing
>Picnic at a chill park/lake
Make it cute, put effort into it, it's lunch with some nice scenery and gives you a more out of the ordinary opportunity to talk over lunch without it feeling like a typical restaurant date
>Farmer's market
This is just a cute outing to go look at something local in your area, get an idea for each other's tastes. It's low commitment, doesn't have to be expensive, and pretty flexible for dates and time
>Arcade
People don't go to these things alone, and as an adult it's not often your friends will hit you up to go to an arcade right. But literally who wouldn't enjoy an afternoon of skeeball and shitty but still cute prizes
>Food truck and an outdoor walk
Get some new food neither of you have tried and just walk around enjoying the fresh air and talking. Super casual, you could window shop or stop by any cool places you see along the way, it leaves a lot of room open for what you want to end up doing while still being a planned date

>>27979697
Nta but this stat is a bit misleading. First, average is not the same as median - it gets skewed by large numbers at the top. The median is just under $70,000 for 2022. Second, income is not the same as salary. Income can count other money that comes to you throughout the year through inheritance, gifts, etc., so the salary itself is probably lower. And finally, that doesn’t take age into account, and most of the high earners are over 50. Picrel shows median annual earnings at around $50,000 for the 25-34 age bracket. So >>27979647 don’t feel bad, you are doing great and it is genuinely impressive from the standpoint of how hard you probably worked to get there. All of that said, I’m a woman who doesn’t care about salary and significantly outearns my boyfriend. There’s no salary that will be a factor in attracting women like me.

>The loneliness and worthlessness I feel is so strong that most days I consider killing myself.
One of my favourite quotes from Nietzsche (from the 3rd essay in genealogy iirc) goes something like this:

Man would rather will nothingness than will nothing at all.

That is, in nihilism and depression, we will ourselves into a catatonic state of hibernation, the lowest possible state of physical energy to sustain a painful and self-pitying wakefulness - so strong is the power of our will that we are driven to kill ourselves rather than endure willing nothing at all. I am reminded of this insight everytime I impulsively entertain depressive or suicidal thoughts. Certainly, a creature whose will is strong enough to drive its body and spirit to death is a powerful one. And I say to myself, "if I am powerful enough to kill myself, I must also be powerful enough to live."

posts.com: I want to get good at drawing cute anime girls, where do I start? What books/videos should I follow? I tried following some tutorials and doing some stuff on my own but nothing good has come out of it, everything looks wonky amd weird and I'm kinda lost.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
first of all drawing just takes a long time.
i suppose at least 95% of people would say they cant draw hands or faces. thats just bs. everyone can draw this. you just take your time. honestly most peoples opinion on art is completely worthless. 'you can't do that' - 'you have to do this' and all this shit, never forget: everything in art is a valid strategy. there is no wrong art. theres no cheating.
i recommend you take some manga or waifu picture that you really like and try to copy the style. first of all you need to get your proportions right. how tall is a head compared to the shoulders? how long is an arm? etc. I generally start my projects with simple large stick figures because its fast. you want to study front views for this (like your op image).
the next step is perspective. it is much harder because you have to distort the figure into a 3d room. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3D_projection
The next thing you want to bother with is lighting and shadows. also, every anime character usually has a distinctive silhouette (= if you color the entire character full black, is it still recognizable?).
dont bother too much with books or videos. try to copy the actual masters. dont forget that you have infinite zoom, undo/eraser and layers. theyre all extremely strong tools.

It may surprise you, but yes, I would still feel uneasy even with total support. First, you need to understand that I'm extraordinarily conscious of my health. I only drink water and milk, I eat eat clean (get all my macros and micros without supplements), and I am extremely active.

Things I don't do: coffee, alcohol, smoking, vaping, marijuana, shrooms, hard drugs, OTC and prescription drugs (as much as I can help it), gamble, casual sex, cable TV, streaming, YouTube, video games, social media, watch sports, news media

Yeah I watch a good movie, look stuff up on YouTube, or play a video game with friends from time to time, but none of these things are habits for me nowadays. One of the only sources of questionable instant gratification in my life is this sexual interest. And like I've said, I've struggled with porn and masturbation for almost a decade. So, in light of all the good work I've done to do right by my body in life, I fear this is just another enemy to vanquish, something that can only exist as an addiction that will make balance and true happiness impossible. Stepping back for a moment though, I'm not sure if there's any person who ever really denied themselves all the more vulgar passions. Maybe part of being successful at the serious, hard things in life is rewarding yourself with some easy joys. Sometimes I feel like the ideal is being a simple laborer in a simple world who uses the strength of his body under the sun and takes care of his family. But isn't the reality that the people like that, both historically and those that still exist today, end their day with drinking, gambling, or smoking a pipe on the porch? Even with a wonderful partner, good friends, and plenty of virtuous hobbies, don't we all dance with some demon?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I love her.
Just typing this is bringing tears to my eyes. We were friends since we were 15. When our lives went off the rails at 19 we were always beside each other. At 20 it caught fire. We spent so many days in her aunt's basement or my childhood bedroom lazily in bed, laughing, listening to music, smoking, looking into each others' eyes, making out, having sex, but the best part was just falling asleep next to each other, knowing we'd wake up and do it all over again. We had nothing, but we had everything. We didn't put words to it, because we thought there was no need - at least I did.
Things change. She moved 1500 miles away for college. I stayed. She got into the art scene over there. I got my degree and a 9 to 5 job. She got engaged. I had other lovers, but in the back of my mind I always compared them to her. I tried my best to move on, but there was always her picture in my mind no matter how much I tried to bury it. Seven years passed.
She came back into town for christmas two days ago. She invited me to a christmas party at her parents' house. She told me she ended her relationship with her fiance and lost her job. Once everyone went to bed we went back to her room and we did everything and everything felt just like it did seven years ago. She leaves on the 28th.
I have to tell her I love her before that happens. I know she's going through a hard time, and she's in a very vulnerable place, and life isn't like a Hallmark christmas movie where the lead girl drops everything and moves across the country to be with the guy, but if I don't tell her now I'll regret it for the rest of my life. She doesn't have to move 1500 miles to be with me - I just want her to know that I love her and I want to tell her in person while I can.
Wish me luck, /adv/
Thanks for reading my diary, lol. I'm a little drunk.
Merry christmas.

>>27978817
Morally gray. In theory it reduces a sale of a license to support the artists, if it is still commercially accessible. However, this does not take into account
- if it's no longer commercially available
- if it's commercially available in your region
- if it's reasonably priced in your region
- if you would have purchased the content if you couldn't have pirated it

For myself, there was software I used when I was older. Games I bought from IPs I pirated when I was younger. Movies I paid to see from franchises I pirated at a younger age. Never would have bought them had I not played them as a kid. And I'd never had bought them as a kid if I couldn't have pirated them.

Take it for what you will. Ask why you do it. Understand how it may impact your future self.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27978817
I think about it a lot
The clear cut case of it being "no" would be the same as the legal reason for ROMs and MP3s etc being that you own the original disc or cartridge or casette tape whatever and just want to have it as a digitized format, it's a backup.

"probably not" would be stuff that's completely out of print so to speak, stuff like old arcade games and games that were never ported to digital shops for whatever reason.

"maybe" would be stuff that's so ancient it's public domain and also the top-grossing movies and artists of all time.

Everything else yeah no it's stealing lol I always tell myself I'll buy the CD or vinyl if there is but I never do I have close to a terabyte of music and CDs cost at least 25$ on average that's I don't like 10 thousand dollars worth of music that I kinda reverse-stole via duplication.

masking. it's a skill.

I'm 25 and im just now starting to learn what masking is and what it means to be autistic. till now i treated it with hatred and denial. i didnt want to accept that i have any limit to what i can do. i travelled the world, learned many skills, but still saw that masking has its limit. it's charming and fun but it is never the real thing, it's always just a mask. it wears me down from the inside and takes a tremendous amount of energy to keep up.

you can get really good at masking. you can develop a charming persona, one that's fully capable of empathy and style and grace. but even if it gets you bitches, it'll always only be a mask. you will find it near impossible to find hot bitches to treat you right when you're not masking and you're just being your regular self. it sucks, to know that who i am underneath it all is the opposite of everyone else wants to be, to know i'll never be popular or pimpin. but it sucks even more to pretend otherwise.

just be chill. it'll come to you if it'll come to you.

I was a pretty troubled child. I followed a fairly typical autism route, sensory integration disorder, social and emotional delays, OCD, etc. I was also abnormally aggressive and violent both in actions and in my personal interests. Things were not easy obviously (for me or for my parents) but I was intelligent enough to succeed in school and I learned enough about social interaction to become acceptable at it. Now I'm in my early 20s, I get good grades at a nice college, I exercise regularly and eat well, and I can socialize acceptably. Basically I am having success at every material aspect of my life.
The trouble is my internal life. I feel that I've learned how to represent myself externally but internally I haven't progressed at all. I have no friends, I have weird behaviors, I have the same aggression, et cetera. All of the problems I dealt with as a child are still there in the exact same form. I haven't even matured meaningfully in ways that you'd think would happen for everybody (e.g. I never developed a sex drive).
I'm not sure how to improve this feeling, if there is any kind of way. I feel very locked in, but I don't know what the solution to that is - if I am "locked in," I can't let myself out without jeopardizing my success in life. Everything about the way I present myself is fake. I know that authenticity is kind of a meme, but I don't think there is not a single aspect of my life that is authentic, and that is hard for me.
Sorry for the wall of text, it's hard for me to be succinct. Merry Christmas also.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>27977734
Miami if you prefer the heat and humidity, NYC if you can deal with the cold. NYC has far more people and therefore more social opportunities. Remember though that New York is a high tax state and generally will have higher rents, whereas Florida has zero income tax and likely lower rent. Texas also has low rent and low tax, but if you move to Florida you also get a beach so Florida over Texas is a no-brainer.

Generally though you want somewhere with a lot of people. SF is smaller than you'd think. San Jose is trash (nothing to do, it's all medium-rise urban sprawl). I live in CA and can't recommend coming here unless you're drawn here by work, friends, or family. We are also overrun by woke lefty politics, which may or may not bother you. A high tech salary could make it worth it. But if you're starting from zero and work is not a factor, you might as well avoid.

Do not go to the the Pacific Northwest (Seattle), it's overdue for a catastrophic earthquake that will fuck over all the cities in the region. Google Cascadia Subduction Zone to learn more.

>>27978646
Read Marcus Aurelius' Meditations.

Yes. Nobody cares. And if you manage to achieve anything in life, the people who will have admired you while you are alive will die, much like yourself, and so will their (and your) offsprings. The more generations die, the lower the chances that anyone will ever appreciate your contribution to this world. You will be forgotten in time and your work will lose value. In the digital age, your best bet is to become a name on Wikipedia. If you don't achieve recognizability while you are alive, you will never be aware that you ever were remotely important.

Can you name all the incredible actors who died in the past few years? John Hurt? Kirk Douglas? What about architects, painters, writers, and similar? Nobody cares, nobody remembers. These people are Wikipedia pages.

The only way you can become truly immortal is to be a human who had a significant effect on human history through their direct actions, for ill or good, like Hitler, Stalin, Caesar.

Art has been utterly commercialized and devalued with digitalization, you have no hope of ever achieving the historical significance than, for example, Michelangelo, Picasso, Dali, or whoever else, and even these guys stop being recognizable once you go beyond the scope of Western world.

But you need to realize that you are here once. Decide what is your purpose in this world and pursue it while being a decent human being that is a force for good. There is nothing wrong by deciding to chill and lay back. There is nothing wrong by deciding that you want to achieve greatness.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Don't focus on happiness. Happiness is a temporary feeling that is meant as a reinforcing element for your evolutionary imperatives. You feel happy when you eat sweet and salty foods regardless of their health value (fruit vs candy) or when you orgasm regardless of the source (partnered sex vs jerking off to futa).
Aim instead for contentment, which is a combination of faith, esteem, and fulfillment. This means accepting the good things in your life and what good things can come, rather than wallow in the self-defeating mindsets you have espoused in your post. It also provides justification for doing work not only for yourself but for those around you. When you make yourself a valuable member of your family and community, you should implicitly want to care for yourself in your health and wealth. It makes it so you're not improooving to some arbitrary goal, but to something concrete and practicable.
It all starts with the decision to accept contentment and acknowledge or reject that which gets in the way of it.

>>27977213
I think expecting that dynamic out of your platonic relationships is going to cause you a lot of stress because I don't know people who regularly do that. I've only had that suggestion made to me a few times that I would be good with their friend.

I don't ever think of playing matchmaker with people in my friend groups. I don't think it's an unwelcome gesture, it's certainly wonderful but maybe you have this expectation from that one off experience?

Placing the expectation of what you want from your friends because they would do it for you I would argue isn't healthy. A lot of my friends would loan money to me but I can't say I'd do the same for them for a number of reasons. I think it'd be odd for them to be irritated at my lack of willingness simply because they would do it for me.

For a lot of women, mixing friends and romance like that can be a good way to really botch group dynamics and burn bridges if it goes south. I don't really blame anyone for being reserved or nonexistent on that front.
